Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language can have inclusive and exclusive social effects, and can empower or disempower people
Elaboration: Identifying language that seeks to align the listener or reader; for example, “of course”, “obviously”, “as you can imagine”
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •ranking language examples from most inclusive to most exclusive

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language can have inclusive and exclusive social effects, and can empower or disempower people
Elaboration: Identifying the use of first person (“i”, “we”) and second person (“you”) pronouns to distance or involve the audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language can have inclusive and exclusive social effects, and can empower or disempower people
Elaboration: Identifying language used to reference or indicate shared assumptions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language can have inclusive and exclusive social effects, and can empower or disempower people
Elaboration: Identifying language that appeals to shared cultural knowledge, values and beliefs

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language can have inclusive and exclusive social effects, and can empower or disempower people
Elaboration: Identifying examples of language that are inclusive or marginalising

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that language used to evaluate, implicitly or explicitly reveals an individual's values
Elaboration: Identifying explicit expressions of values when evaluating
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •building vocabulary to identify if a speaker or author is supporting, questioning or criticising a position, for example ‘affirms’ – supporting, ‘explores’ – questioning, ‘rejects’ – criticising

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that language used to evaluate, implicitly or explicitly reveals an individual's values
Elaboration: Identifying subtle or implied values communicated through language; for example, using a term such as “teenager” to refer to an individual rather than using a specific name

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse text structures and language features and evaluate their effectiveness in achieving their purpose
Elaboration: Comparing the text structure and language features of a print text transposed to an online environment and evaluating the effectiveness of the online text
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •detailed guidelines of text structure and language features typically aligned to particular text purposes

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse text structures and language features and evaluate their effectiveness in achieving their purpose
Elaboration: Analysing the text structures and language features of reviews from different sources, and evaluating their effectiveness

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse text structures and language features and evaluate their effectiveness in achieving their purpose
Elaboration: Analysing and experimenting with combinations of graphics, text and sound in the production of multimodal texts such as documentaries, media reports, online magazines and digital books to influence audience responses

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how paragraph structure can be varied to create cohesion, and paragraphs and images can be integrated for different purposes
Elaboration: Examining how authors vary paragraph structures for effect
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •explanation of ways cohesion is created in paragraphs and multiple opportunities to review paragraph structure and discuss the ways in which text and images work together for a particular purpose, for example in graphic novels, picture books and media reports

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how paragraph structure can be varied to create cohesion, and paragraphs and images can be integrated for different purposes
Elaboration: Examining the integration of paragraphs and images on websites for effect

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how paragraph structure can be varied to create cohesion, and paragraphs and images can be integrated for different purposes
Elaboration: Evaluating the effect of the integration of paragraphs and images in graphic novels

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate the effectiveness of particular sentence structures to express and craft ideas
Elaboration: Recognising how the focus of a sentence can be changed through using the passive voice; for example, compare active “the police had caught the thief.” with passive “the thief had been caught.”
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •graphic organisers to consider aspects of sentence structure, for example sentence length, sentence beginnings, word order, punctuation

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate the effectiveness of particular sentence structures to express and craft ideas
Elaboration: Recognising how the focus of a sentence can be changed through using the passive voice; for example, compare active “the police had caught the thief.” with passive “the thief had been caught.”
EALDElaboration: •multiple opportunities to practise identifying clause structure, restructuring clauses and discussing the effect, selecting sentences appropriate to students’ level of English language proficiency

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate the effectiveness of particular sentence structures to express and craft ideas
Elaboration: Recognising how authors sometimes use verbless clauses for effect; for example, “and what about the other woman? with her dark glasses and briefcase.”

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate the effectiveness of particular sentence structures to express and craft ideas
Elaboration: Recognising that a sentence can begin with a coordinating conjunction for stylistic effect; for example, “and she went on planning how she would manage it.”

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how meaning and style are achieved through syntax
Elaboration: Considering how nominalisation affects the way in which events are constructed and explained, making some information more explicit than other information
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher explanation and opportunities to practice reconstructing complex sentences into a simple sentence with dense noun phrases, for example ‘After thoroughly exploring the cave, I found a rare egg.’ ‘The thorough exploration led to a rare discovery.’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how meaning and style are achieved through syntax
Elaboration: Analysing how logical relations between ideas are built up by combining main with subordinate clauses indicating cause, result, manner, concession, condition, and so on; for example, “although the poet was not generally well received by critics during her life (concession), her reputation grew substantially after her death.”

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how meaning and style are achieved through syntax
Elaboration: Considering how abstraction in a noun group allows for greater generalisation of complex ideas in a sentence; for example, “he focused on the political, religious, social and economic elements of the society in his thesis.”

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Evaluate the features of still and moving images, and the effects of those choices on representations
Elaboration: Examining features of visual texts that create nuance in representations; for example, analysing the use of light and dark, and evaluating the impact of light and dark on representing duplicity
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •dictionary of the terms used to name features of still and moving images

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use an expanded technical and academic vocabulary for precision when writing academic texts
Elaboration: Identifying the meaning of an increasing range of technical vocabulary; for example, using specific terms about rhythm such as “iambic pentameter” when analysing poetry
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •developing a personal dictionary of academic vocabulary, including examples and the opportunity to explain terms using home language.

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how authors use and experiment with punctuation
Elaboration: Using colons and semicolons in expositions and other extended texts to add detail or extend an idea
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •clear guidelines on the range of punctuation and contexts for use

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how authors use and experiment with punctuation
Elaboration: Examining an author’s use of ellipses to create tentativeness in a character’s speech

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how authors use and experiment with punctuation
Elaboration: Reviewing the use of punctuation to represent emotions; for example, the use of multiple exclamation marks or punctuation emojis

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse representations of individuals, groups and places and evaluate how they reflect their context in literary texts by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Analysing the ways in which cultural stories may be retold and adapted across a range of contexts, such as the story of the “anti-hero”, and evaluating how the “anti-hero” reflects the context
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •clear explanations of the historical, social and cultural context of literary texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse representations of individuals, groups and places and evaluate how they reflect their context in literary texts by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Analysing the ways in which cultural stories may be retold and adapted across a range of contexts, such as the story of the “anti-hero”, and evaluating how the “anti-hero” reflects the context
EALDElaboration: •teacher-supported discussions of how representations result from conscious or unconscious choices by the author and opportunities to explore examples of this

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse representations of individuals, groups and places and evaluate how they reflect their context in literary texts by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Analysing how stories written by first nations australian authors contemporise or modernise traditional stories and evaluating the responses of contemporary audiences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse representations of individuals, groups and places and evaluate how they reflect their context in literary texts by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Analysing how humour is used to represent the underdog in australian texts and evaluating how the underdog reflects the context

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Reflect on and extend others’ interpretations of and responses to literature
Elaboration: Debating whether a text possesses universal qualities and retains relevance
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •alternative ways of demonstrating this, such as a small group discussion, a visual representation, a teacher interview, or graphic organiser

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Reflect on and extend others’ interpretations of and responses to literature
Elaboration: Presenting arguments based on close textual analysis to support an interpretation of a text; for example, writing an essay or creating a set of director’s notes

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Reflect on and extend others’ interpretations of and responses to literature
Elaboration: Creating personal reading lists in a variety of genres and explaining why texts qualify for inclusion on a particular list

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Analyse how the aesthetic qualities associated with text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features, and the context in which these texts are experienced, influence audience response
Elaboration: Examining a range of texts and evaluating the effect of text structures and language features; for example, determining whether the narrative position of a child evokes reader sympathy towards an event or issue
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •exploring a range of short texts with familiar content and accessible language, to focus on a particular aesthetic feature such as a symbol or metaphor and record the emotion evoked by this feature

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Evaluate the social, moral or ethical positions represented in literature
Elaboration: Identifying and analysing ethical positions on a significant issue, including values and/or principles involved, and evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of the position presented
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •exploring texts with familiar content and accessible language, to illustrate how a moral or ethical position is represented

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how text structure, language features, literary devices and intertextual connections shape interpretations of texts
Elaboration: Examining a range of short poems, a short story, or extracts from a novel or film to find and discuss examples of how language devices layer meaning and influence the responses of listeners, viewers or readers
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •support in exploring intertextuality by explaining the cultural and historical context of the original text referred to and using graphic organisers to record the connection to the newer text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how text structure, language features, literary devices and intertextual connections shape interpretations of texts
Elaboration: Examining satirical representations of events or ideas and determining how satire shapes interpretations and responses

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Compare and evaluate how “voice” as a literary device is used in different types of texts, such as poetry, novels and film, to evoke emotional responses
Elaboration: Comparing the “voice” of protest in a range of poems or songs and evaluating how different voices evoke a response
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to listen to examples of "voice” in recordings of poetry and plays and in texts in their home language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate the aesthetic qualities of texts
Elaboration: Using terms associated with literary text analysis; for example, “stanza”, “figurative language”, “symbolism” and “soundtrack”, when evaluating aspects that are valued and that contain aesthetic qualities
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •developing a personal dictionary of aesthetic features of text, with examples and explanations using home language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate the aesthetic qualities of texts
Elaboration: Analysing and evaluating the use of literary devices; for example, commenting on the effect of symbolism in a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts with a sustained “voice”, selecting and adapting text structures, literary devices, and language, auditory and visual features for purposes and audiences
Elaboration: Experimenting with the aesthetic features that authors use in their own texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher-supported joint construction of texts to build confidence in selecting text structures and literary devices

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts with a sustained “voice”, selecting and adapting text structures, literary devices, and language, auditory and visual features for purposes and audiences
Elaboration: Experimenting with the aesthetic features that authors use in their own texts
EALDElaboration: •guided or shared editing of texts to ensure a sustained “voice”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts with a sustained “voice”, selecting and adapting text structures, literary devices, and language, auditory and visual features for purposes and audiences
Elaboration: Creating a range of texts, experimenting with and manipulating “voice” for particular purposes and audiences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts with a sustained “voice”, selecting and adapting text structures, literary devices, and language, auditory and visual features for purposes and audiences
Elaboration: Creating and editing a suite of short texts that focus on a key idea expressed in different voices

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts with a sustained “voice”, selecting and adapting text structures, literary devices, and language, auditory and visual features for purposes and audiences
Elaboration: Describing choices of text structures, literary devices, language, auditory or visual features made in a literary text and reflecting on the effect of those choices

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how people, places, events and concepts are represented in texts and reflect contexts
Elaboration: Evaluating stereotypes of people, places, events and concepts, and expressing opinions on these representations in the contexts for which they are created
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •identifying cultural contexts within texts and build students’ background knowledge prior to reading

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how people, places, events and concepts are represented in texts and reflect contexts
Elaboration: Analysing representations of events and issues in first nations australian media

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen to spoken texts and explain the purposes and effects of text structures and language features, and use interaction skills to discuss and present an opinion about these texts
Elaboration: Analysing spoken and multimodal features of media texts and discussing the effects of these features; for example, presenting an opinion on the combination of words and sound in creating mood
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •previewing key concepts, background knowledge, vocabulary and listening purpose prior to listening •using visual supports and prompts to support oral explanations and when presenting opinions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how language features are used to implicitly or explicitly represent values, beliefs and attitudes
Elaboration: Analysing social or political cartoons to identify the implicit and explicit values, beliefs and attitudes expressed
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of contemporary visual and media texts from a range of cultural contexts and teacher-supported discussions how attitudes within them are represented

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how authors organise ideas in texts to achieve a purpose
Elaboration: Identifying the organisation of ideas in a text and determining the purpose and effect; for example, how the eye is drawn across or down a webpage for a purpose
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using a concept map to provide a visual representation of the organisation of ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how authors organise ideas in texts to achieve a purpose
Elaboration: Evaluating how ideas in an online review are organised and its success in achieving its purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how authors organise ideas in texts to achieve a purpose
Elaboration: Comparing the organisation of ideas in political pamphlets and determining the impact of each

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Integrate comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to analyse and interpret complex and abstract ideas
Elaboration: Monitoring the language features associated with right and wrong in a text and interpreting the representation of the abstract concept of justice
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using visuals such as graphic organisers or retrieval charts to help students identify and organise ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Integrate comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to analyse and interpret complex and abstract ideas
Elaboration: Interpreting how visual features represent abstract concepts in advertising, such as the representation of parenthood in advertisements

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Integrate comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to analyse and interpret complex and abstract ideas
Elaboration: Summarising the qualities and interpreting the role of a character archetype in a range of texts and analysing the importance of this archetype

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising, expanding and developing ideas through experimenting with text structures, language features, literary devices and multimodal features for specific purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Presenting a structured argument by providing a statement of the major arguments or concerns relating to an issue, previewing the structure of arguments, structuring the text to provide a major point for each paragraph with succinct elaboration, and concluding with a summary of the main issues or recommendations in an argument
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher–supported deconstruction of model texts, modelling of the planning process and joint construction of sample paragraphs or texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising, expanding and developing ideas through experimenting with text structures, language features, literary devices and multimodal features for specific purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Creating written and multimodal texts that compel readers to empathise with the ideas and emotions expressed or implied

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising, expanding and developing ideas through experimenting with text structures, language features, literary devices and multimodal features for specific purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Designing a webpage that combines navigation, text, sound, and moving and still images for a specific audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising, expanding and developing ideas through experimenting with text structures, language features, literary devices and multimodal features for specific purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Reviewing, editing and refining their own and others’ texts for accuracy of grammar, spelling and punctuation, and to achieve particular purposes and address specific audiences through control and organisation of content, sentence structures, vocabulary choices and visual features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising, expanding and developing ideas through experimenting with text structures, language features, literary devices and multimodal features for specific purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Reflecting on the effect of choices made in a written or multimodal text and how these choices may be changed or developed in future texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations by experimenting with rhetorical devices, and the organisation and development of ideas, to engage audiences for different purposes in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Taking the role of a character in a reflective monologue, and considering and justifying actions and choices at a critical moment in the text
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •listening to spoken texts that employ rhetorical devices such as hyperbole and repetition, and recording their response to those devices

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations by experimenting with rhetorical devices, and the organisation and development of ideas, to engage audiences for different purposes in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Taking the role of a character in a reflective monologue, and considering and justifying actions and choices at a critical moment in the text
EALDElaboration: •teacher deconstruction of language, visual and multimodal features of model presentations.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations by experimenting with rhetorical devices, and the organisation and development of ideas, to engage audiences for different purposes in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Creating spoken multimodal texts that manipulate rhetorical devices to compel listeners to act

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations by experimenting with rhetorical devices, and the organisation and development of ideas, to engage audiences for different purposes in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Discussing and negotiating with peers in debates and panel discussions about issues related to a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of the spelling system to spell words and to manipulate standard spelling for particular effects
Elaboration: Using homophones to create new spelling of familiar words; for example, “lite milk”
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •explanation of how the manipulated version differs from the original and in what contexts this would be accepted.
